awd_titl_txt: Examining the Dynamics of Rainbands and Secondary Eyewall Formation in Tropical Cyclones
awd_abstract_narration:
Hurricane size and intensity can be affected by changes in the inner core of a storm.  One of the dramatic changes is the development of a secondary eyewall.  Despite the importance of the secondary eyewall, competing theories exist regarding how they develop and their interactions with hurricane rainbands.  This project will use a combination of observations from hurricane reconnaissance aircraft and the latest in numerical modeling to fill a critical gap in scientific understanding of tropical cyclone evolution.  The main societal impact from the award would be through improved tropical cyclone forecasts, especially in the crucial hours before landfall.  The project will also help to train the next generation of scientists.

The research team plans to study the dynamics behind the transition of tropical cyclone inner core rainbands into a secondary eyewall.  The researchers contend that current theories for secondary eyewall formation (SEF) do not explain the exact dynamical pathway that connects rainbands to SEF.  To make progress on this topic, the team will combine observational analysis and numerical modeling.  The observational analysis will include data from a total of 38 SEF events that were well sampled by the NOAA P-3 Hurricane Hunter aircraft over the past two decades.  The modeling aspect will focus on more recent events, such as Harvey, Irma, and Maria, making use of the Penn State Weather Research Forecasting - Ensemble Kalman Filter (WRF-EnKF) system.  The main objectives of the project are to:   (1) Identify and characterize coherent rainband features that occurred in observations prior to secondary eyewall formation and compare to those rainbands in storms that did not develop secondary eyewalls, (2) Examine the rainband features leading to secondary eyewall formation in real-case model simulations and compare to those in observations, (3) Explore the ubiquity and predictability of rainband dynamics that lead to secondary eyewalls through systematic ensemble sensitivity experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Accurate forecasts of tropical cyclones (TCs) are critical for disaster planning and reducing the loss of life and property during a landfalling TC. But forecasters face significant challenges with predicting TC intensity and rainfall. This is in part due to our incomplete understanding of TC physics, particularly regarding TC features like rainbands and secondary eyewalls. To address these challenges, a series of research projects have been undertaken, employing a combination of radar observations and computer modeling to advance knowledge of TCs.

Airborne radar observations from the NOAA Hurricane Research Division’s Tail Doppler Radar were used to analyze the updrafts in TC rainbands observed over a 10 year span. This project examined statistics of updraft characteristics (e.g., velocity, depth, storm location, local circulation pattern) in many storms, and provided a better understanding of the frequency, location (with respect to the large-scale environmental wind shear), and variability of rainband updraft structures. Rainband updrafts tended to be strongest and most frequent in the downshear-left quadrant of the storm. The overall pattern of the updrafts’ local radial flow largely follows the background shear-induced radial flow at near the updraft base and top, which suggests that the local circulations are significantly influenced by the large-scale environmental wind shear.

Ground-based radar observations from the NOAA National Weather Service operational radar network were used to examine the precipitation particle properties (i.e., microphysics) in Hurricanes Matthew (2016) and Irma (2017). TC microphysics significantly impact TC features but remain poorly understood. An analysis of these two storms has found that new precipitation (convective) growth and older precipitation (stratiform) fallout occurred mostly in expected regions (relative to the environmental wind shear) of the storm. Specifically, the inner eyewall precipitation exhibited a clear signature of spatial sorting by precipitation size in the expected location of the maximum updraft in the eyewall. These findings will contribute to improving the representation of TC microphysics in models.

Simplified (idealized) model simulations were used to better understand changes in the TC wind field that correspond to rainband evolution and formation of a secondary eyewall. By replicating the basic thermodynamics of broader, old-growth stratiform precipitation in a TC rainband, the major circulation responses were a descending inflow pattern that drove a cold pool of air toward the surface, which also led to new, persistent rainband updrafts. A separate study showed that persistent rainband updrafts can be simulated in an idealized boundary layer particularly in storm quadrants that have an expanded, enhanced wind field. Observations show that this broadened wind field occurs most prevalently in the downshear storm quadrants. Given that a descending inflow pattern often leads to enhanced winds, these combined findings suggest that stratiform rainband processes may be early catalysts of persistent updrafts that form secondary eyewalls in TCs.

The implications of rainband and secondary eyewall processes from the radar and idealized model studies of rainband and secondary eyewall processes were further analyzed in a real-case, full-physics, high-resolution model simulation of Hurricane Matthew (2016). In this simulation, the wind and precipitation structures were consistent with observations and the idealized simulations, including the descending inflow, the surface cold pool air, an expanded wind field, and new, persistent updrafts in the stratiform region of the rainband complex These new updrafts were directly attributed to driving the formation of the secondary eyewall, further supporting a dynamical pathway that connects rainbands to secondary eyewall formation.

In summary, these research efforts represent a multifaceted approach to understanding the dynamics of rainbands and secondary eyewalls in tropical cyclones. By combining observational data and computer modeling methods, this work has advanced fundamental understanding of these TC features and how they may be linked to changes in TC intensity and size. These findings hold promise for improving the representation of TC evolution in forecast models and ultimately improving the accuracy of TC forecasts.
